DataElement.preferredDefinition: A description of chronic lymphocytic leukemia classification.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: The most common type of chronic lymphoid leukemia.  It comprises 90% of chronic lymphoid leukemias in the United States.  Morphologically, the neoplastic cells are small, round B-lymphocytes.  This type of leukemia is not considered to be curable with available therapy. (WHO, 2001)_A method of generalization, the systematic arrangement of entities into classes or groups based on mutual similarity and certain differing characteristics.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: The most common type of chronic lymphoid leukemia, and comprises 90% of chronic lymphoid leukemias in the United States.  Morphologically, the neoplastic cells are small, round B-lymphocytes.  The clinical course is indolent, but this type of leukemia is not considered to be curable with available therapy. (WHO, 2001) -- 2003

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Specification of human conditions relevant to cancer. This includes observations, test results, history, and other concepts relevant to characterization of human cancer-related conditions. Non-neoplastic conditions of interest are also included.

PermissibleValues.value: Chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL), B-cell / small lymphocytic lymphoma (SLL)
PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia Small Lymphocytic Lymphoma

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia Small Lymphocytic Lymphoma
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The most common type of chronic lymphoid leukemia.  It comprises 90% of chronic lymphoid leukemias in the United States.  Morphologically, the neoplastic cells are small, round B-lymphocytes.  This type of leukemia is not considered to be curable with available therapy. (WHO, 2001): A non-Hodgkin lymphoma composed of monomorphic small, round B-lymphocytes in the lymph nodes.  When the lymphoid process predominantly involves the bone marrow and the peripheral blood it is called chronic lymphocytic leukemia. (WHO, 2001)

Concepts.definition: The most common type of chronic lymphoid leukemia.  It comprises 90% of chronic lymphoid leukemias in the United States.  Morphologically, the neoplastic cells are small, round B-lymphocytes.  This type of leukemia is not considered to be curable with available therapy. (WHO, 2001)

A non-Hodgkin lymphoma composed of monomorphic small, round B-lymphocytes in the lymph nodes.  When the lymphoid process predominantly involves the bone marrow and the peripheral blood it is called chronic lymphocytic leukemia. (WHO, 2001)

RepresentationTerm.preferredName: Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia Histology Classification Type
RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: The most common type of chronic lymphoid leukemia. It comprises 90% of chronic lymphoid leukemias in the United States. Morphologically, the neoplastic cells are small, round B-lymphocytes. This type of leukemia is not considered to be curable with available therapy. (WHO, 2001):The study of the structure of the cells and their arrangement to constitute tissues and, finally, the association among these to form organs.  In pathology, the microscopic process of identifying normal and abnormal morphologic characteristics in tissues, by employing various cytochemical and immunocytochemical stains.:A method of generalization, the systematic arrangement of entities into classes or groups based on mutual similarity and certain differing characteristics.:Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.

Concepts.definition: The most common type of chronic lymphoid leukemia.  It comprises 90% of chronic lymphoid leukemias in the United States.  Morphologically, the neoplastic cells are small, round B-lymphocytes.  This type of leukemia is not considered to be curable with available therapy. (WHO, 2001)

The study of the structure of the cells and their arrangement to constitute tissues and, finally, the association among these to form organs.  In pathology, the microscopic process of identifying normal and abnormal morphologic characteristics in tissues, by employing various cytochemical and immunocytochemical stains.
A method of generalization, the systematic arrangement of entities into classes or groups based on mutual similarity and certain differing characteristics.
Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.
